concept.title: Reading hierarchies
concept.shortdesc: In addition to task, concept, and reference hierarchies, you can combine information types to form a reading sequence of topics.

conbody.p: The task, concept, and reference hierarchies provide a logical organization that can help users understand various aspects of use: the expected usage flow, the conceptual underpinnings of a product, and the details of its functionality. The hierarchies are meaningful in this sense even in themselves, without the content they organize. However, the hierarchies are designed to aid understanding of topics retrieved when they are needed, and are not meant to provide a reading sequence. Few readers will have the patience to read the whole set of concepts without wanting to find out about tasks, and few readers will be able to read all tasks without resorting to reference information for more detail on some point or other.

While the typed hierarchies provide appropriate organizations for users to retrieve information when it is needed, they do not provide appropriate organizations for more intensive reading efforts. To support readers who have the time and discipline to read the whole of a documentation set, we can provide a more sequence-friendly organization, which mixes concepts, tasks, and references together, including each topic only once.

You can also choose to build a map like this directly, instead of building maps organized by type. However, you should still go through the exercises of identifying a scenario, identifying tasks, and then identifying concepts and reference information, before building your mixed map. Even if you don't expose the task, concept, and reference hierarchies to your users, they are still valuable tools for building a minimalist manual.
